pullRequest.body:
We show that a union of sets in a semiring can be written as the disjoint unions of sets in the semiring, and add several lemmas. 

First PR in a work towards the Caratheodory extension theorem, when starting with a `SetSemiring`.

<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:

```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Oh, and first of all: thanks for your PR and welcome to mathlib! Your PR looks pretty nice, especially for a first PR.

There are two independent things in this PR: a useful theorem on set semirings, and a cosmetic change in the file Mathlib/Order/CompleteLattice.lean, replacing => with ↦. In general, it is better if a PR is focused on one thing, and I'm not completely sure about the cosmetic change (there are varying tastes, and if we do it one day I think we will do it over all mathlib, with a script, in one go). So I'd remove this change from the PR.

And thanks for the PR!

> There are two independent things in this PR: a useful theorem on set semirings, and a cosmetic change in the file Mathlib/Order/CompleteLattice.lean, replacing => with ↦. In general, it is better if a PR is focused on one thing, and I'm not completely sure about the cosmetic change (there are varying tastes, and if we do it one day I think we will do it over all mathlib, with a script, in one go). So I'd remove this change from the PR.
> 
> And thanks for the PR!

There are two statements hidden in `CompleteLattice.lean`, which I need in `Semiring.lean`. (They are about a (fin)set of sets, and since they can be formulated more generally using a complete lattice, I put them there.) I removed all the other changes (of => to ↦).
The PR is not building, and still marked awaiting-author. Is there still something you want to change/fix?
Yes, indeed I forget to rename some things in `AddContent`, which use the renamed versions. It builds now.

> I still have naming issues (but I think we're almost there). I'm really sorry to inflict this on you, but the naming convention is really important to manage a library of the size of mathlib.

Thanks for your patience...

:v: pfaffelh can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13040933450/job/36382394888)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13040933450/job/36382395224)

bors d+
Thanks!

I took a look at your PR from a style/design point of view. There are optional style suggestions, and some things I would do differently on first instinct. Perhaps my instinct is wrong/you considered and realised your design is better, but it would be good to consider these thoughts resp. document why you prefer your set-up.

I took a look at your PR from a style/design point of view. There are optional style suggestions, and some things I would do differently on first instinct. Perhaps my instinct is wrong/you considered and realised your design is better, but it would be good to consider these thoughts resp. document why you prefer your set-up.
I still have naming issues (but I think we're almost there). I'm really sorry to inflict this on you, but the naming convention is really important to manage a library of the size of mathlib.
One last round of comments! When you're happy with your changes, please don't forget to remove the `awaiating-author` tag, so that I know you're done.

bors d+
Thanks!
Mathlib style is to have the colon at the end of the line. Can you do so, please? If you have trouble with the line length, you could also move a hypothesis to the next line.
Thanks, hypothesis is in new line now.
Optional: mathlib slightly prefers "\mapsto" over "=>".
Ok, changed all instances of => in the file to ↦
Optional: you could inline some of the short goal proofs here. (I tend to like that more; that may be my personal opinion.)
Ok, I have shortened a bit by defining less and made two terms inline.
I could inline K' here, given you only use that once, right?
Yes, done.

I wonder if that's the best way to state this result, for two reasons:
- your conclusion mentions an existential quantifier, so every application will have to use `choose`: that's a bit burdensome (as you can see below)
A different possible design could be to have a `def` returning such a set, possibly with a big scary comment that this is a non-canonical choice.

- having a statement with six properties can be cumbersome to work with: you'll have to use obtain/rcases to unpack them all the time. You *could* also create a structure for these properties.

This is not to say that my suggestions are necessarily better! However, I wonder if that's a better design - so at least, it would be good to discuss why you choose the design you went with.

As far as I can tell, that big theorem is not meant to be ever used elsewhere and is only written that way because it's convenient for the induction proof (there could be a comment that warns not to use it).
It's not meant to be used in applications: it is followed by a definition that gives a choice for the existential, and a list of properties. For the same reason, you don't need to use `rcases` or `obtain` to unpack the properties: you would use the API defined below.
Given all that, I think the statement is fine?

Thanks for the comment, I did think about this. The definition is not to be used anywhere other than the proof I am aiming for (Caratheodorys Theorem). If I pack all in a `structure`, I would only use that `structure` in a single definition. There are similar constructions already in lines 70 and 208.

Do you know about the [hypotheses left of colon rule](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html#hypotheses-left-of-colon) from the mathlib style guide? I would think this applies here (or you should say why it's better to do differently).
Right, now all hypothesis are to the left.

These two lemmas have the same conclusion up to a simp, and `allDiffFinset₀_pairwiseDisjoint'` is the better one since it gives its result in simp normal form. I would keep only that one (and remove the prime from the name):
```suggestion
lemma allDiffFinset₀_pairwiseDisjoint (hC : IsSetSemiring C) (hJ : ↑J ⊆ C) :
    (⋃ x ∈ J, (hC.allDiffFinset₀ hJ x).toSet).PairwiseDisjoint id :=
  (Exists.choose_spec (hC.allDiffFinset₀_props hJ)).2.2.1
```
Ok, done.
You should change that lemma such that the result is what you get after the `simp` and the proof is only `(Exists.choose_spec (hC.allDiffFinset₀_props hJ)).2.2.2.2.2`.
ok, done.

These two lemmas have the same conclusion, except that the first one is in simp normal form while the second one is not. I think we should keep only the first one:
```suggestion
lemma allDiffFinset₀_subsets_semiring (hC : IsSetSemiring C) (hJ : ↑J ⊆ C) (hj : j ∈ J) :
    (allDiffFinset₀ hC hJ j).toSet ⊆ C :=
  (Exists.choose_spec (hC.allDiffFinset₀_props hJ)).2.1 _ hj
```
ok, done.

We should find a better name for that, because the current one is a bit obscure. `disjointSubsets`? Also the type of the def should appear:
```suggestion
noncomputable def disjointSubsets (hC : IsSetSemiring C) (hJ : ↑J ⊆ C) : Set α → Finset (Set α) :=
```

Ok. But then, we should also rename `diffFinset` to `disjointSubsetsOfSetdiff` and `diffFinset₀` to `disjointSubsetsOfSetdiffUnion` or so? I suspect yes, therefore I used the name `disjointSubsetsOfUnion`, as well as the other renamings...

Sorry I forgot about the existing `diffFinset` name when making that suggestion and did not think about having coherent names between those.

I don't know what name we should use, but  `allDiffFinset` just feels hard to understand.

```suggestion
  * `⋃ x ∈ J, K x` are pairwise disjoint and do not contain ∅,
```
ok

```suggestion
lemma pairwiseDisjoint_allDiffFinset₀ (hC : IsSetSemiring C) (hJ : ↑J ⊆ C) :
```
Better follow the same order for the lemma name as for the symbols in the lemma statement: this makes the lemma more discoverable.
ok

```suggestion
lemma allDiffFinset₀_subset (hC : IsSetSemiring C) (hJ : ↑J ⊆ C) (hj : j ∈ J) :
```
as `allDiffFinset₀` only makes sense in a semiring context, no need to specify it again in the lemma statement.
ok, done.
Ha, this clashes with the name I suggested above. Maybe `sUnion_allDiffFinset₀_subset_self` for this one.

```suggestion
lemma allDiffFinset₀_subset_self (hC : IsSetSemiring C) (hJ : ↑J ⊆ C) (hj : j ∈ J) :
```
ok, done.

```suggestion
lemma empty_nmem_allDiffFinset₀ (hC : IsSetSemiring C) (hJ : ↑J ⊆ C) (hj : j ∈ J) :
```
Again, the lemma name should follow the order of symbols in the lemma statement.
Done, and changed `non_mem` to `nmem` in other instances, too.
That seems very long. What about just `IsSetSemiring.disjointOfDiff`? It's still expressive enough with the main features (construct disjoint stuff out of a difference), while shorter to read.
Ok, I see. Yes, they are really long. I changed `disjointSubsets` ↦ `dosjoint` and `Setdiff` ↦ `Diff` in all names.
And this one would just be `disjointOfDiffUnion`.
See above.

And this one would be `disjointOfUnion`. Could you also specify the type (i.e., say that it is a map `Set α → Finset (Set α)`). Better even, put the `Set α` as a variable left of the colon, for readability.
See above.`Set α` is left of the colon.

The docstring seems to indicate that you're building a finite set of subsets, but that's not the case, you're building a map. Could you clarify the docstring? Also, can you explain why your design is better than a more naive finite set of subsets?

Docstring is changed. I need this constcuction since I need to formulate ⋃₀ K j ⊆ j for j ∈ J. This is needed in a proof of subadditivity of an `addCotent m` in the next PR. There, I write m ⋃₀ J = ⋃₀ ⋃ x ∈ J, (K x) = ∑ x ∈ J, m ⋃ K x ≤ ∑ x ∈ J, m x by monotonicity.

```suggestion
a `Finset (Set α)` such that `K j := hC.disjointOfUnion hJ j` are disjoint
and `⋃₀ K j ⊆ j`, for `j ∈ J`.
Using these we write `⋃₀ J` as a disjoint union `⋃₀ J = ⋃₀ ⋃ x ∈ J, K x`.
See `MeasureTheory.IsSetSemiring.disjointOfUnion_props`.-/
noncomputable def disjointOfUnion (hC : IsSetSemiring C) (hJ : ↑J ⊆ C) (j : Set α) : 
    Finset (Set α) :=
```
I added a `j` in the definition of `K j` in the docstring, reflowed the lines, and added the type in the definition to help the readers.
Thanks.
I don't think you merged this one.
Indeed, sorry. Is merged now.

Can you avoid `toSet`, here and below? It's a coercion, so it should be as transparent as possible. For instance, here you can write it as
```suggestion
    PairwiseDisjoint J (hC.disjointOfUnion hJ) :=
```
I haven't replaced all the other ones below, but you should probably remove all of them, either completely if it's possible, or putting an explicit coercion arrow `↑` when it's necessary.
There is no more `toSet`. I either have used the uparrow, or write `... : Set (Set α))`.

```suggestion
lemma disjointOfUnion_subset (hC : IsSetSemiring C) (hJ : ↑J ⊆ C) (hj : j ∈ J) :
    ↑(disjointOfUnion hC hJ j) ⊆ C :=
```
renamed to follow the order of symbols in the statement (note that you should never use `subsets` in a lemma name, because there is no such concept in mathlib), and replace `toSet` with the coercion.
Ah, right, there are no subsets, this is just notation... Hmm, this means that the whole file could be formulated on some distributive lattice, I guess. Would this be a good or a bad idea?

No, sorry, what I meant is that `subset` is perfectly fine, while `subsets` is not. I don't think it would be a good idea to switch to distributive lattices, as it will only be used in sets. If someone needs this in a more general context some day, they will do the adaptation themself.
There were two more `subsets`, I changed their names.

```suggestion
lemma  pairwiseDisjoint_biUnion_disjointOfUnion (hC : IsSetSemiring C) (hJ : ↑J ⊆ C) :
```
Changed.

```suggestion
lemma pairwiseDisjoint_disjointOfUnion (hC : IsSetSemiring C) (hJ : ↑J ⊆ C) (hj : j ∈ J) :
```
This already exists, used `pairwiseDisjoint_disjointOfUnion_of_mem`.

```suggestion
lemma disjointOfUnion_subset (hC : IsSetSemiring C) (hJ : ↑J ⊆ C) (hj : j ∈ J) :
```
to follow the order of symbols
That also exists already, used `disjointOfUnion_subset_of_mem`.
could you put the `x` left of the colon, and rename the lemma `subset_of_mem_disjointOfUnion`?
Done.

```suggestion
    ⋃₀ ⋃ x ∈ J, hC.disjointOfUnion hJ x = ⋃₀ (J : Set (Set α)) :=
```
put the most complicated term to the left of the lemma (so that it matches the lemma name better, and is more suited to rewrites or simplifier uses), and avoid `toSet`. Also, `:=` should be on the statement line, not the next one. Note that you will need to add `.symm` to the next line to account for the side change.
Done, this makes sense.

```suggestion
lemma empty_nmem_disjointOfDiffUnion (hC : IsSetSemiring C) (hs : s ∈ C)
```
Changed.

```suggestion
lemma subset_of_mem_disjointOfDiffUnion (hC : IsSetSemiring C) (hs : s ∈ C) (hI : ↑I ⊆ C)
```
This is the same name as below, I use `subset_of_diffUnion_disjointOfDiffUnion` here.
put `t` left of the colon, and rename the lemma to `subset_of_mem_disjointOfDiffUnion`.
Done.

```suggestion
variable {j : Set α} {J : Finset (Set α)}
```
Instead, start the proof of `disjointOfUnion_props` with `classical`.
Didn't know this trick. Done.

```suggestion
lemma pairwiseDisjoint_biUnion_disjointOfUnion (hC : IsSetSemiring C) (hJ : ↑J ⊆ C) :
```
Done.

```suggestion
      exact_mod_cast hK1_of_ne _ (ne_of_mem_of_not_mem hx hJ)
```
Done.

```suggestion
          exact_mod_cast h7
```
Done.
I don't understand this comment.
I streamlined the proof a bit more, and deleted the comment. (It was supposed to say that transitivity is used.)

```suggestion
lemma subset_diff_of_mem_disjointOfDiffUnion (hC : IsSetSemiring C) (hs : s ∈ C) (hI : ↑I ⊆ C)
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(MeasureTheory/SetSemiring.lean, Order/CompleteLattice.lean): change SetSemiring allow writing unions as disjoint unions

source.title: (sub-)additivity of an addContent on a (semi-)ring of sets

nodes.body: I still have naming issues (but I think we're almost there). I'm really sorry to inflict this on you, but the naming convention is really important to manage a library of the size of mathlib.

  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13040933450/job/36382394888)
